articles.headline: Japan’s Strict Building Codes Saved Lives
articles.snippet: Perhaps no country in the world is better prepared to withstand earthquakes and tsunamis than Japan.
articles.abstract: Perhaps no country in the world is better prepared to withstand earthquakes and tsunamis than Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hidden inside the skeletons of high-rise towers, extra steel bracing, giant rubber pads and embedded hydraulic shock absorbers make modern Japanese buildings among the sturdiest in the world during a major earthquake. And all along the Japanese coast, tsunami warning signs, towering seawalls and well-marked escape routes offer some protection from walls of water.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Norimitsu Onishi

articles.headline: Europeans Reach New Deal to Fight Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: Greece will receive a cut in its interest rate and a bailout fund will become more flexible.
articles.abstract: Greece will receive a cut in its interest rate and a bailout fund will become more flexible.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders agreed early Saturday to new measures intended to end the euro zone debt crisis, offering the debt-laden Greece a cut in its interest rate and injecting more flexibility into the way a bolstered bailout fund for the euro can be used.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: A Red Flag on Reverse Mortgages
articles.snippet: A HUD rule that could force the home of a surviving spouse into foreclosure raises another warning flag about tapping home equity in retirement.
articles.abstract: A HUD rule that could force the home of a surviving spouse into foreclosure raises another warning flag about tapping home equity in retirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the saddest of paradoxes: a government-backed financial maneuver intended to free up extra money for struggling older people turns out to have left some widows and widowers on the brink of foreclosure.

articles.headline: In Libya Revolt, Youth Will Serve, or at Least Try
articles.snippet: Boys as young as their early teens have left their homes in hopes of joining the opposition forces.
articles.abstract: Boys as young as their early teens have left their homes in hopes of joining the opposition forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAS LANUF, Libya  The bullet the boy held was bigger than his hand. He said he was 15, but then admitted he was 14, and frankly, he looked a year or two younger than that. When an enemy warplane approached, sending the gunmen around him scrambling for cover, the boy, with placid poise, stood and watched.

articles.headline: U.S. Inquiry on Military Family Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is looking into claims that a unit of Morgan Stanley illegally foreclosed on almost two dozen military families.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is looking into claims that a unit of Morgan Stanley illegally foreclosed on almost two dozen military families.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is investigating allegations that a mortgage subsidiary of Morgan Stanley foreclosed on almost two dozen military families from 2006 to 2008 in violation of a longstanding law aimed at preventing such action.

articles.headline: Facebook Users Who Are Under Age Raise Concerns
articles.snippet: Many young people lie about their ages to create accounts on social networks, and there is no way to stop them.
articles.abstract: Many young people lie about their ages to create accounts on social networks, and there is no way to stop them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The fake ID has gone digital, and spread to elementary school.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Give Up Familiar Light Bulb? Not Without Fight, Some Say
articles.snippet: A law on light bulb efficiency due to take effect next year has brought a frenzy of activity to get the law repealed or, at least, to stockpile the bulbs before they disappear from store shelves.
articles.abstract: A law on light bulb efficiency due to take effect next year has brought a frenzy of activity to get the law repealed or, at least, to stockpile the bulbs before they disappear from store shelves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American protests against the encroachment of government have been spurred by many causes  tea, of course, and guns, frequently. The latest catalyst: light bulbs.

articles.headline: Japanese Scramble to Avert Meltdowns as Nuclear Crisis Deepens After Quake
articles.snippet: Japanese officials said Sunday they presumed partial meltdowns had occurred at two crippled reactors and that they were facing serious cooling problems at three more.
articles.abstract: Japanese officials said Sunday they presumed partial meltdowns had occurred at two crippled reactors and that they were facing serious cooling problems at three more.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese officials struggled on Sunday to contain a widening nuclear crisis in the aftermath of a devastating earthquake and tsunami, saying they presumed that partial meltdowns had occurred at two crippled reactors and that they were facing serious cooling problems at three more.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Japan Pushes to Rescue Survivors as Quake Toll Rises
articles.snippet: Japan mobilized a nationwide rescue effort for survivors in collapsed buildings and for thousands without water, electricity, heat or telephone service.
articles.abstract: Japan mobilized a nationwide rescue effort for survivors in collapsed buildings and for thousands without water, electricity, heat or telephone service.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAKAMINATO, Japan  While nuclear experts were grappling with possible meltdowns at two reactors after the devastating earthquake and ensuing tsunami in northern Japan, the country was mobilizing a nationwide rescue effort to pluck survivors from collapsed buildings and rush food and water to hundreds of thousands of people without water, electricity, heat or telephone service.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Mark McDonald

articles.headline: Arab League Endorses No-Flight Zone Over Libya
articles.snippet: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pushed rebels eastward as the Arab League asked the U.N. Security Council to impose a no-flight zone.
articles.abstract: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pushed rebels eastward as the Arab League asked the U.N. Security Council to impose a no-flight zone.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Arab League asked the United Nations Security Council on Saturday to impose a no-flight zone over Libya in hopes of halting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s attacks on his own people, providing the rebels a tincture of hope even as they were driven back from a long stretch of road and towns they had captured in the three-week war.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Google’s Quest to Build a Better Boss
articles.snippet: A company study found that a manager’s technical skills were far less valued by employees than people skills.
articles.abstract: A company study found that a manager’s technical skills were far less valued by employees than people skills.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mountain View, Calif.

articles.headline: A Swift Deal May Not Be a Sound One
articles.snippet: Attorneys general seem to be rushing into a bank settlement related to loan-servicing and foreclosure practices. But how can conclusions be reached without a full-fledged investigation?
articles.abstract: Attorneys general seem to be rushing into a bank settlement related to loan-servicing and foreclosure practices. But how can conclusions be reached without a full-fledged investigation?
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE crucial reason the nation’s mortgage industry ran itself — and the entire nation — off the rails was its obsession with speed. Mortgages had to be approved chop-chop, loans pooled instantly. When it came to foreclosure, well, the quicker the better.

articles.headline: A Changed Starbucks. A Changed C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Howard Schultz was humbled as Starbucks closed stores in the recession. Now he is thinking more like a manager and less like an entrepreneur.
articles.abstract: Howard Schultz was humbled as Starbucks closed stores in the recession. Now he is thinking more like a manager and less like an entrepreneur.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE

articles.headline: Death Toll Estimate in Japan Soars as Relief Efforts Intensify
articles.snippet: Military and civilian teams continued their grim work as Japan faced mounting humanitarian emergencies and the death toll climbed.
articles.abstract: Military and civilian teams continued their grim work as Japan faced mounting humanitarian emergencies and the death toll climbed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SENDAI, Japan — Japan reeled from a rapidly unfolding disaster of epic scale on Sunday, pummeled by the death toll, destruction and homelessness caused by the earthquake and tsunami and new hazards from damaged nuclear reactors that were leaking radiation. The prime minister called it Japan’s worst crisis since World War II.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Mark McDonald

articles.headline: Amazon Pressured on Sales Tax
articles.snippet: States struggling with deficits want Amazon.com to take on a role it does not want: tax collector.
articles.abstract: States struggling with deficits want Amazon.com to take on a role it does not want: tax collector.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Across the country, state officials struggling with big budget shortfalls are trying to get Amazon.com to take on a role it does not want: tax collector.

articles.headline: At Crossroads, Libya Rebels Vow to Stand or Die
articles.snippet: After another day of retreat, rebels prepared for what some called a last stand at Ajdabiya, where government forces are advancing.
articles.abstract: After another day of retreat, rebels prepared for what some called a last stand at Ajdabiya, where government forces are advancing.
articles.lead_paragraph: AJDABIYA, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced Sunday on this anxious town, a strategic linchpin on the doorstep of the opposition capital Benghazi and within grasp of a highway crucial to recapturing the eastern border and encircling the rebellion with heavy armor and artillery.

articles.headline: Campaigning as All Things to All Republicans
articles.snippet: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, stands out among the major contenders in trying to court all factions.
articles.abstract: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, stands out among the major contenders in trying to court all factions.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — Many aspiring Republican presidential candidates are going to great lengths to avoid the spotlight, but not Tim Pawlenty. He is doing whatever he can to step into it.

articles.headline: Founder of a Provocative Web Site Forms a New Outlet
articles.snippet: Canvas, a new Web site by Christopher Poole, the founder of the notorious 4chan site, has attracted interest and financing from respected venture capitalists.
articles.abstract: Canvas, a new Web site by Christopher Poole, the founder of the notorious 4chan site, has attracted interest and financing from respected venture capitalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For most entrepreneurs, running a Web site that is rife with pornography and frequently criticized as a menace to society would not be considered a résumé booster. Many venture capitalists would head in the opposite direction.

articles.headline: Disruptions of Power and Water Threaten Japan’s Economy
articles.snippet: The crisis at damaged nuclear plants north of Tokyo was threatening to cause an energy crunch that could hobble Japan’s economy.
articles.abstract: The crisis at damaged nuclear plants north of Tokyo was threatening to cause an energy crunch that could hobble Japan’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the humanitarian and nuclear crises in Japan escalated after the devastating earthquake and tsunami, the impact on the country’s economy appeared to be spreading as well.

articles.headline: Radioactive Releases in Japan Could Last Months, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Experts in Japan and the United States said that the releases from nuclear plants could go on for weeks or months. Officials are also reporting a new explosion.
articles.abstract: Experts in Japan and the United States said that the releases from nuclear plants could go on for weeks or months. Officials are also reporting a new explosion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the scale of Japan’s nuclear crisis begins to come to light, experts in Japan and the United States say the country is now facing a cascade of accumulating problems that suggest that radioactive releases of steam from the crippled plants could go on for weeks or even months.
articles.byline: By DAVID E. SANGER and MATT WALD

articles.headline: The News, in Bright Bits
articles.snippet: The Week, with its bite-size articles, the full arc of opinion and a skinny format is growing where other newsweeklies are lagging.
articles.abstract: The Week, with its bite-size articles, the full arc of opinion and a skinny format is growing where other newsweeklies are lagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Somewhere along the line, utility became a bad word at news magazines. And that’s where The Week saw an opening.

articles.headline: Gains for NPR Are Clouded
articles.snippet: Lately, NPR has often been better at making news than running a news organization.
articles.abstract: Lately, NPR has often been better at making news than running a news organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pew Project for Excellence in Journalism will issue its annual State of the Media report on Monday, and you will be unsurprised to learn that journalism remains in broad retreat.

articles.headline: Need Overwhelms Japan After Quake and Tsunami
articles.snippet: Hundreds of bodies are washing up along some shores, making clearer Japan’s extraordinary death toll and adding to the burdens of relief workers as they ferry aid and search for survivors.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of bodies are washing up along some shores, making clearer Japan’s extraordinary death toll and adding to the burdens of relief workers as they ferry aid and search for survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATORI, Japan — What the sea so violently ripped away, it has now begun to return. Hundreds of bodies are washing up along some shores in northeastern Japan, making clearer the extraordinary toll of the earthquake and tsunami that struck last week and adding to the burdens of relief workers as they ferry aid and search for survivors.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Mark McDonald

articles.headline: Japan Faces Potential Nuclear Disaster as Radiation Levels Rise
articles.snippet: Japan faced the likelihood of a catastrophic nuclear accident after an explosion further damaged one of the crippled reactors and a fire at another spewed large amounts of radioactive material into the air.
articles.abstract: Japan faced the likelihood of a catastrophic nuclear accident after an explosion further damaged one of the crippled reactors and a fire at another spewed large amounts of radioactive material into the air.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s nuclear crisis verged toward catastrophe on Tuesday after an explosion damaged the vessel containing the nuclear core at one reactor and a fire at another spewed large amounts of radioactive material into the air, according to the statements of Japanese government and industry officials.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi, David E. Sanger and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Renault Apologizes to Employees Fired in Spy Case
articles.snippet: The arrest of the security agent is the latest development as the case against three Renault executives accused of industrial espionage continues to unravel.
articles.abstract: The arrest of the security agent is the latest development as the case against three Renault executives accused of industrial espionage continues to unravel.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Renault apologized on Monday to three executives that it had accused of industrial espionage as the focus of the inquiry turned to an internal security agent who had been investigating the case.

articles.headline: Saudi Troops Enter Bahrain to Help Put Down Unrest
articles.snippet: Saudi officials said that about 1,000 of their troops had entered Bahrain. Opposition groups denounced the move as a foreign occupation.
articles.abstract: Saudi officials said that about 1,000 of their troops had entered Bahrain. Opposition groups denounced the move as a foreign occupation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — Saudi Arabia’s military rolled into Bahrain on Monday, threatening to escalate a local political conflict into a regional showdown with Iran.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Michael Slackman
